sectionTitle: Chapter: The prohibition of killing a disbeliever after he says La ilaha illallah
Chapter: The Saying of the prophet (saws): "Whoever bears weapons against us is not one of us."
Chapter: The Saying of the prophet (saws): "Whoever deceives us is not one of us."

Chapter: Clarifying the emphatic prohibition of letting one's garment hang below the ankles (isbal), reminding others of one's gift and selling goods by means of a false oath; Mention of the three to whom Allah, Most High, will not speak on the day of resurrection, nor look at them, nor sanctify them, and theirs will be a painful torment
Chapter: Clarifying the emphatic prohibition against killing oneself; The one who kills himself with something will be punished with it in the fire; And that no one will enter Paradise but a muslim
Chapter: Emphatic prohibition against stealing from the spoils of war; and that no one will enter paradise except the believers
Chapter: The evidence that the one who kills himself is not considered a disbeliever
Chapter: Regarding the wind which will come just before the resurrection and take the soul of anyone who has any fath in his heart
Chapter: Encouragement to hasten to do good deeds before the emergence of the Fitnah
Chapter: Islam destroys that which came before it, as do Hijrah (Emigration) and Hajj

Chapter: Clarification that Allah, most high allows a person's thoughts and whatever occurs in his heart, so long as they do not become established, and the clarification that he, glorious is he and most high, does not burden anyone with more than he can bear, and clarifying the ruling on thinking of doing good and bad deeds
Chapter: If a person thinks of doing a good deed it will be recorded for him, and if he thinks of doing a bad deed it will not be recorded for him
Chapter: Clarifying the Waswasah (Whispers, Bad Thoughts) with regard to faith, and what the one who experiences that should say

Chapter: The evidence that the blood of one who aims to seize other people's wealth without right may be shed, if he is killed he will be in the fire, and the one who is killed defending his property is a martyr
Chapter: Clarifying that Islam started as something strange, and will revert to being something strange, and it will retreat between the two Masajid
Chapter: Permissibility of concealing one's faith in the case of fear
Chapter: Obligation of believing that the message of our Prophet Muhammad (saws) is for all people, and the abrogation of all other religions

Chapter: The descent of 'Eisa bin Mariam to judge according to the Shari'ah of our Prophet Muhammad (saws); And how Allah has honored this Ummah; And clarifying the evidence that this religion will not be abrogated; and that a group from it will continue to adhere to the truth and prevail until the day of resurrection
Chapter: Clarifying the time when faith will no longer be accepted
Chapter: The night journey on which the messenger of Allah (saws) was taken up into the heavens and the prayers were enjoined
Chapter: Mentioning Al-Masih Son of Mariam and Al-Masih ad-Dajjal
Chapter: About (The Lote-Tree of the Utmost Boundary)
Chapter: The Meaning of the Saying of Allah, The Mighty and Sublime: And indeed he saw him at a second descent (another time)"; And did the prophet (saws) see his lord on the night of the Isra?
Chapter: Affirming that the believers will see their Lord, Glorious is he and most high, in the hereafter
Chapter: The Last of the people of the Fire to be brought out of it
Chapter: The Status of the Lowest people in paradise
Chapter: Regarding the saying of the Prophet (saws): "I will be the first of the people to intercede concerning Paradise, and I will be the Prophet with the Greatest Number of Followers."
Chapter: The Prophet (saws) will defer his supplication in order to intercede for his ummah
Chapter: The supplication of the Prophet (saws) for his ummah and his weeping out of compassion for them
Chapter: Clarifying that whoever died upon disbelief then he is in the Fire, and no intercession or relationship with those who are close to Allah will be of any avail for him
Chapter: Regarding the saying of Allah, the most High: "And warn your tribe of near kindred."

Chapter: The least severely punished of the people of the Fire
Chapter: The evidence that whoever dies upon disbelief, no good deed will benefit him
Chapter: Allegiance to the believers, and forsaking others and disavowing them
Chapter: The Evidence that groups of Muslims will enter Paradise without being called to account, and without being punished
Chapter: The virtue of wudu’

Chapter: The permissibility of performing all the prayers with one wudu’

Chapter: The obligation to wash away urine and other impurities if they result in the Masjid, and the ground may be purified with water with no need to scrub it

Chapter: It is recommended to seek refuge with Allah from the punishment of the grave, the punishment of hell, the trials of life and death, the tribulation of the Dajjal and from sin and debt between the tashah-hud and the taslim
Chapter: From what refuge is to be sought when in salat
Chapter: It is recommended to recite statements of remembrance after the prayer, and how that is to be done
Chapter: What is to be said between the opening takbir and the recitation of the Qur’an
Chapter: When should the people stand up to pray?
Chapter: The one who catches up with a rak`ah of the prayer, he has caught up with that prayer
Chapter: The recommendation to delay Zuhr (until it has cooled down) in severe heat for one who finds it too hot in route to join the congregation
Chapter: It is recommended to pray Zuhr at the beginning of its time when there is no intense heat
Chapter: It is recommended to pray `Asr early
Chapter: The evidence for those who say that “the middle prayer” is the `Asr prayer
Chapter: The beginning of the time for Maghrib when the sun sets
Chapter: The time of `Isha and delaying it
Chapter: The virtue of prayer in congregation, and clarifying the stern warning against staying away from it, and that it is fard kifayah
Chapter: It is obligatory for the one who hears the call to prayer to come to the masjid
Chapter: It is permissible to offer voluntary prayers in congregation, and to pray on hasir (palm-fiber mats), khumrah (small mats), cloth, and other pure things
Chapter: The virtue of taking many steps to the masjid
Chapter: Walking to prayer erases sins and raises one in status
Chapter: The virtue of sitting in one’s prayer place after Subh, and the virtue of the masajid

Chapter: It is recommended to say qunut in all prayers if a calamity befalls the Muslims – and refuge is sought from Allah (regarding that). It is recommended to say qunut in Subh at all times. And the clarification that it is to be said after raising the head from bowing in the final rak`ah, and it is recommended to say it out loud
Chapter: Making up a missed prayer. And it is recommended to hasten to make it up
Chapter: The travelers’ prayer and shortening it
Chapter: Praying in dwellings when it is raining
Chapter: It is permissible to offer voluntary prayers atop one’s mount when travelling, no matter what direction it is facing

Chapter: It is disliked to start a voluntary prayer after the Mu’adhdhin has started to say Iqamah for prayer, whether that is a regular sunnah, such as the sunnah of Subh or Zuhr, or anything else, and regardless of whether he knows that he will catch up with the rak`ah with the Imam or not
Chapter: It is recommended to pray two rak`ah in the masjid for one who has come from a journey, when he first arrives
Chapter: It is recommended to pray Duha, the least of which is two rak`ah, the best of which is eight, and the average of which is four or six, and encouragement to do so regularly

Chapter: It is recommended to pray two rak`ah for the sunnah of Fajr. And encouragement to pray them regularly, and to make them brief, and to persist in offering them, and clarifying what is recommended to recite therein
Chapter: The virtue of the regular sunnah prayers before and after the obligatory prayers, and their numbers
Chapter: It is permissible to offer voluntary prayers standing or sitting, and to stand and sit in the same rak`ah
Chapter: Night prayers and the number of rak`ah offered by the Prophet (saws) at night, and that Witr is one rak`ah, and a one-rak`ah prayer is correct
Chapter: Night prayer, and the one who sleeps and misses it or is sick
Chapter: The night prayers are two by two, and Witr is one rakah at the end of the night
Chapter: The prayer and the supplication of the Prophet (saws) at night
Chapter: It is recommended to recite for a long time in the night prayers
Chapter: Encouragement to pray at night even if it is little
Chapter: It is recommended to offer voluntary prayers in one’s house although it is permissible to offer them in the masjid
Chapter: The command to one who becomes sleepy while praying, or who starts to falter in his recitation of the Qur’an or statements of remembrance, to lie down or sit down until that goes away
Chapter: The command to keep refreshing one’s knowledge of the Qur’an and that it is disliked to say I have forgotten such-and-such a verse, but it is permissible to say I have been caused to forget
Chapter: The descent of tranquility (sakinah) when the Qur’an is recited
Chapter: The virtue of reciting the Qur’an in prayer and learning it
Chapter: The virtue of reciting the Qur’an and Surat al-Baqarah
Chapter: The virtue of al-Fatihah and the closing verse of Surat al-Baqarah; and the encouragement to recite the two verses at the end of Surat al-Baqarah
Chapter: The virtue of Surat al-Kahf and Ayat al-Kursi
Chapter: The virtue of reciting Qul Huwa Allahu Ahad
Chapter: The virtue of one who acts in accordance with the Qur’an and teaches it. And the virtue of one who learns wisdom from Fiqh or other types of knowledge, then acts upon it and teaches it
Chapter: The times when it is forbidden to offer salat
Chapter: How `Amr bin `Abasah became Muslim
Chapter: Concerning the two rak`ah that the Prophet (saws) used to pray after `Asr
Chapter: It is recommended to pray two rak`ah before Maghrib
Chapter: Those Who Say That He Prayed With Eight Bowings And Four Prostrations
Chapter: The Call For The Eclipse Prayer: "As-Salatu Jami'ah (The Prayer Is Being Assembled)
Chapter: Prompt the Dying person to say La Ilaha Ill-Allah
Chapter: What is to be said in the presence of the sick and the dying
Chapter: Crying for the deceased
Chapter: Visiting the sick
Chapter: The deceased is tormented because of his family's crying for him
Chapter: Stern warning against wailing
Chapter: Shrouding the deceased well
Chapter: If one hundred (people) pray for a person, they will intercede for him
Chapter: If forty people pray for a person, they will intercede for him
Chapter: Saying the takbir over the deceased
Chapter: Praying over the grave
Chapter: The Lahd (Niche), and setting up bricks over the deceased
Chapter: Putting a piece of velvet in the grave
Chapter: The command to level the grave
Chapter: What is to be said when entering the graveyard and supplicating for its occupants
Chapter: Leaving the funeral prayer for one who committed suicide
Chapter: On what one-tenth or half of one-tenth is due
Chapter: Paying or withholding Zakat
Chapter: The virtue of spending on one's family and slaves, and the sin of the one who neglects them or withholds maintenance from them
Chapter: The virtue of spending and giving charity to relatives, spuses, children and parents, even if they are idolaters
Chapter: The word charity (Sadaqah) may apply to all good deeds Ma'ruf
Chapter: The one who spends and the one who withholds
Chapter: Encouragement to give charity before there is no one to accept it
Chapter: Acceptance of charity that comes from good (Tayyib) earnings, and the growth thereof
Chapter: The virute of giving gifts
Chapter: Confirmation of the reward of the one who gives Charity, even if the Charity ends up in the hands of an evildoer, and the like
Chapter: The reward of the Trustworthy Trustee, and if a woman gives charity from her husband's house without causing any damage, with his explicit or implicit permission
Chapter: What a slave spends of his master's wealth
Chapter: The virtue of the one who does other kinds of good deeds in addition to giving charity
Chapter: Encouragement to give in charity even if it is a little, and a little should not be withheld because one thinks it is too little
Chapter: The upper hand is better than the lower hand, and the upper hand is the one that gives and the lower hand is the one that receives
Chapter: It is disliked to beg from people
Chapter: The one for whom it is permissible to ask for help
Chapter: If the Son of Adam had two valleys, he would desire a third
Chapter: The virtue of contentment and encouragement thereof
Chapter: Sufficient provision and contentment

Chapter: Giving to those whose hearts have been inclined (towards Islam) and to those for whose faith there is fear if they are not given anything, and putting up with the one who asks rudely due to ignorance, and the Khawarij and rulings regarding them
Chapter: Giving to those whose hearts have been inclined (towards Islam) and urging those whose faith is strong to show patience
Chapter: The Khawarij are the most evil of people and of all creation

Chapter: Gifts are permissible for the Prophet (saws) and Banu Hashim and Banu Al-Muttalib, even if the giver acquired it by way of charity. When the receipient takes possession of Charity, it is no longer described as charity, and it is permissible for anyone for whom charity is otherwise unlawful
Chapter: The prophet (saws) accepted gifts but refused Charity
Chapter: The month may be twenty-nine days
Chapter: Each land has its own sighting of the moon, and if they see the crescent in one land, that does not necessarily apply to regions that are far away from it

Chapter: Clarifying that fasting begins at dawn, and a person may eat and other than that until dawn begins; And clarifying the dawn which has to do with the rulings concerning the beginning of fasting and the beginning of the time for the Subh Prayer, and other than that, which is the Second Dawn, which is called the True Dawn. The First Dawn, which is the False Dawn, has nothing to do with the rulings
Chapter: The virtue of sahur, which is recommended. It is recommended to delay it and to hasten the breaking of the fast
Chapter: Clarifying the time for ending the fast and the end of the day
Chapter: The prohibition of Al-Wisal
Chapter: Clarifying that Kissing when fasting is not unlawful for the one whose desire is not provoked by that
Chapter: The fasting is valid for the one who is Junub when dawn comes

Chapter: It is permissible to fast or not to fast during Ramadan for one who is travelling for no sinful purpose, if his journey is two stages or further. But it is better for the one who is able to fast without suffering any harm to do so, and the one for whom it is difficult may break the fast
Chapter: The reward of the one who does not fast when travelling if he does any tasks that are required
Chapter: It is recommended for the person performing Hajj in 'Arafat not to fast on the day of 'Arafah.
Chapter: Fasting on the day of Ashura'
Chapter: Whoever eats on'Ashura, let him refrain (from eating) for the rest of the day
Chapter: The prohibition of fasting on the two days of 'Id
Chapter: Making up fasts on behalf of the deceased

Chapter: If a fasting person is invited to eat and he does not want to break his fast, or someone insults him or argues with him, it is recommended for him to say: "I am Fasting", and he should protect his fast from obscene speech, ignorance and the like
Chapter: The Virtue of Fasting
Chapter: The one who eats, drinks, or has intercourse by mistake does not break his fast
Chapter: The Prophet's Fasts at times other than Ramadan; and it is recommended to ensure that no month is free of fasting
Chapter: It is recommended to fast three days of every month, and to fast on the days of 'Arafah and 'Ashura', and to fast on Mondays and Thursdays
Chapter: The fear prayer
Chapter: Perfume and siwak on Fridays
Chapter: The (special) time that occurs on Friday
Chapter: Jumu`ah prayer is when the sun has passed its zenith
Chapter: The two khutbah before the prayer, and sitting briefly in between them
Chapter: The verse: “And when they see some merchandise or some amusement they disperse headlong to it, and leave you standing”
Chapter: Stern warning against missing Jumu`ah
Chapter: Keeping the prayer and khutbah short
Chapter: The hadith about teaching during the khutbah
Chapter: Concession Allowing Play That Involves No Disobedience During The Days Of 'Id
Chapter: Raising The Hands In Supplication When Praying For Rain
Chapter: The Supplication When Praying For Rain
Chapter: The virtue of Lailat Al-Qadr and the Exhortation to seek it; When it is and the most likely times to seek it
Chapter: Striving harder in worship during the last ten days of Ramadan
Chapter: What one who has entered Ihram for Hajj or Umrah is permitted to wear, and what is not permissible, and perfume is forbidden for him
Chapter: The Talbiyah, its description and timing
Chapter: Praying at the Masjid of Dhul-Hulaifah
Chapter: It is recommended to apply perfume just before entering Ihram, and it is recommended to use Musk, and it does not matter if its glistening traces remain
Chapter: The prohibition of hunting game for the one who has entered Ihram for Hajj or for Umrah or for both
Chapter: Cupping is permissible for the Muhrim (pilgrim in Ihram)
Chapter: The soundness of Ihram for the woman in Nifas; It is recommended for her to perform Ghusl before entering Ihram, and the same applies to one who is menstruating

Chapter: Clarifying the types of Ihram; and that it is permissible to perfom Hajj that is Ifrad, Tamattu and Qiran. It is permissible to join Hajj to Umrah. And when the pilgrim who is performing Qiran should exit Ihram
Chapter: The Standing and the Saying of Allah, The Most High: "Then depart from the place whence all the people depart"
Chapter: It is permissible to base one's intention for Ihram on the intention of another

Chapter: The Obligation For the Pilgrim who is performing Tamattu' to offer a sacrifice; If he has no animal to sacrifice, he must fast for three days during Hajj and seven days when he goes back to his family
Chapter: Ifrad and Qiran

Chapter: Clarifying that the pilgrim who has entered Ihram for Umrah should not exit Ihram after performing Tawaf before Sa'i; And the pilgrim who has entered Ihram for Hajj should not exit Ihram after performing Tawaf Al-Qudum, and the same applies to the pilgrim performing Qiran
Chapter: It is permissible to perform 'Umrah during the months of Hajj
Chapter: Marking and Garlanding the sacrificial animal when entering Ihram
Chapter: It is permissible for the pilgrim performing Umrah to shorten his hair and he does not have to shave it. It is recommended for him to shave his hair or shorten it at Al-Marwah
Chapter: The number of Umrahs performed by the prophet (saws) and when he performed them
Chapter: The virtue of the Umrah performed during Ramadan
Chapter: It is recommended to stay overnight in Dhu Tuwa when intending to enter Makkah, and to perform Ghusl before entering it, and to enter it by day
Chapter: Raml (walking rapidly) is recommended in the Tawaf of Umrah, and in the first Tawaf of Hajj
Chapter: It is recommended to touch the two Yemeni Corners in Tawaf and not the other two corners
Chapter: It is permissible to circumambulate the Ka'bah on a camel and the like, And for one who is riding to touch the (black) stone with a crooked staff and the like.
Chapter: Clarifying that Sa'i between As-safa and Al-Marwah is a pillar of Hajj, without which Hajj is not valid

Chapter: It is recommended to send the weak among women and others ahead from Al-Muzdalifah to Mina at the end of the night, before it gets crowded, but it is recommended for others to stay there until they have prayed Subh in Al-Muzdalifah
Chapter: It is recommended to stone Jamrat Al-'Aqabah, on the day of sacrifice, riding, and the prophet saws said: "Learn your rituals (of Hajj) from me"
Chapter: The number of pebbles for stoning the Jamrahs is seven at a time
Chapter: Shaving the head is preferrable to cutting the hair, although cutting the hair is permissible
Chapter: It is permissible to offer the sacrifice before stoning the Jamrah, or to shave before offering the sacrifice or stoning the Jamrah, or to perform Tawaf before any of them
Chapter: It is recommended to perform Tawaf Al-Ifadah on the day of sacrifice
Chapter: It is recommended to halt at Al-Muhassab on the day of departing from Mina and to perform Zuhr and subsequent prayers there
Chapter: It is obligatory to stay overnight in Mina during the nights of the days of At-Tashriq, and the concession allowing those who supply water to leave
Chapter: It is recommended to sacrifice the camel when it is standing and tied
Chapter: What should be done with the sacrificial animal if it gets injured on the way?
Chapter: The farewell Tawaf is obligatory, but it is waived in the case of menstruating women
Chapter: It is recommended for pilgrims and others to enter the Ka'bah and pray therein, and supplicate in all its corners
Chapter: Hajj on behalf of one who is incapable of doing it because of chronic illness, old age and the like, or on behalf of one who has died
Chapter: Hajj is obligatory once in a lifetime
Chapter: It is recommended to recite statements of remembrance when setting out for Hajj or any other purpose, and the best of this remembrances
Chapter: No idolator may circumambulate the house, and no one may circumambulate the house naked, and when the greatest day of Hajj is
Chapter: The virtue of the day of 'Arafat
Chapter: The sanctity of Makkah and the sanctity of its game, grasses, trees and lost property, except for the one who announces it, is forever
Chapter: The prohibition of carrying weapons in Makkah when there is no need for that
Chapter: It is permissible to enter Makkah without Ihram
Chapter: The virtue of Al-Madinah and the Prophet's Prayer for it to be blessed. Its sanctity and the sanctity of its game and trees. The Boundaries of its sanctuary
Chapter: Encouragement to live in Al-Madinah and to be patient on bearing its distress and hardships
Chapter: Al-Madinah is protected against the plague and the Dajjal entering it
Chapter: Al-Madinah eliminates its Dross and it is also called Tabah, and Taibah
Chapter: The virtue of the area between the prophet's grave and his Minbar, and the virtue of the spot where his minbar is
Chapter: The virtue of Uhud
Chapter: The virtue of praying in the Masajid of Makkah and Al-Madinah
Chapter: Marriage is recommended for the one who desires it and can afford it, and the one who cannot afford it should distract himself by fasting
Chapter: The prohibition of marriage for one who is in Ihram, and it is disliked for him to propose marriage
Chapter: The prohibition of proposing marriage when one's brother has already proposed, unless he gives permission or gives up the idea
Chapter: Prohibition and invalidity of Shighar Marriage
Chapter: Fulfilling the conditions stipulated in the Marriage
Chapter: Seeking permission of a previously-married woman in words, and of a virgin by silence
Chapter: The Dowry. It is permissible for the dowry to be teaching Quran, a ring of iron or anything else, a small or large amount, And it is recommended for it to be Five Hundred Dirham
Chapter: The command to accept invitations
Chapter: It is permissible to have intercourse with a breastfeeding woman (Ghilah), and 'Azl is disliked
Chapter: The daughter of one's brother through breastfeeding is forbidden in marriage
Chapter: One or Two sucks
Chapter: Breastfeeding an adult
Chapter: Dividing one's time among co-wives; The Sunnah is for each one to have one night and one day
Chapter: It is recommended to marry one who is religiously committed
Chapter: Advice with regard to women
Chapter: Giving one's wife the choice does not count as a divorce, unless it is intended as such
Chapter: The woman who has been irrevocably divorced is not entitled to spending
Chapter: It is permissible for a woman who is observing 'Iddah after an irrevocable divorce or the death of her husband to go out during the day if she needs to
Chapter: The 'Iddah of a woman whose husband had died, and the like, ends when she gives birth.
Chapter: The Obligation to mourn during the 'Iddah following the death of one's husband, but it is forbidden to mourn for more than three days in other cases
Chapter: A slave working to pay off the other half
Chapter: Al-Wala' (Right of inheritance) belongs to the one who manumits the slave
Chapter: The prohibition of a manumitted slave taking anyone as a Mawla except the one who manumitted him
Chapter: The invalidity of Hasah transactions and transactions involving ambiguity

Chapter: The prohibition of urging a buyer to cancel a purchase in order to sell him one's own goods; And urging a seller to cancel a sale already agreed upon so that one can buy the goods oneself; And the prohibition of artificially inflating prices; And the prohibition of letting milk accumulate in the udder in order to deceive the purchaser
Chapter: The prohibition of intercepting traders
Chapter: The prohibition of the town-dweller selling on behalf of a bedouin
Chapter: It is invalid to sell goods before taking possession of them
Chapter: The prohibition of selling produce before its goodness appears
Chapter: The prohibition of selling fresh dates in exchange for dry dates except in the case of 'Araya
Chapter: Kira (leasing Land)
Chapter: It is recommended to waive debts
Chapter: The virute of giving more time to one who is suffering difficulty, and letting those go who are suffering difficulty and those who are well off
Chapter: The prohibition of the price of a dog, the fee of a fortuneteller and the payment of a prostitute, and the prohibition of selling cats
Chapter: The command to kill dogs, and its abrogation. The prohibition of keeping dogs, except for hunting, farming, (herding) livestock and the like
Chapter: The prohibition of selling wine
Chapter: Riba (Usury, Interest)
Chapter: Selling Food Like for Like
Chapter: Cursing the one who consumes Riba and the one who pays it
Chapter: The permissibility of selling animals for animals of the same kind and of different quality
Chapter: The prohibition of swearing oaths when selling
Chapter: The prohibition of wrongdoing, seizing land unlawfully etc
Chapter: The width of the road if there is a dispute about it
Chapter: It Is Disliked To Favor Some Of One's Children Over Others In Gift-Giving
Chapter: Bequeathing One-Third
Chapter: The Reward For Charity Reaches The Deceased
Chapter: What Reward Reaches A Man After His Death
Chapter: Waqf (Endowment)
Chapter: Not Making A Will For One Who Has Nothing To Be Bequeathed
Chapter: One Who Vows To Walk To The Ka'bah
Chapter: Expiation For Breaking A Vow
Chapter: Whoever swears by Al-Lat and Al-Uzza, let him say La Ilaha Illallah
Chapter: The prohibition of persisting in an oath that will harm the family of the one who swears it, so long as not persisting in it does not involve anything unlawful
Chapter: Feeding a slave what one eats and clothing him as one clothes oneself, and not burdening him with more than he bear
Chapter: The reward of a slave who is sincere towards his master and worships Allah properly
Chapter: The validity of Qisas for teeth and the like
Chapter: The Diyah for a fetus; and the Diyah for accidental killing and the ambiguous killing must be paid by the shahiqilah of the killer
Chapter: Cutting off the hand of a thief from the nobility and others; the prohibition of interceding with regard to Hudud punishments
Chapter: One who confesses to Zina
Chapter: Stoning Jews and Ahl Adh-Dhimmah for Zina
Chapter: Number of lashes in the case of ta'zeer
Chapter: The obligation of judging on the basis of a witness and an oath
Chapter: The best of witnesses
Chapter: It is recommended for a judge to reconcile between disputants
Chapter: Milking animals is unlawful if the owner has not given permission
Chapter: It is recommended to spend surplus wealth
Chapter: It is recommended to mix provisions if they are few, and to share them out
Chapter: The command to show leniency and avoid causing aversion (towards Islam)
Chapter: The prohibition of betrayal
Chapter: Permissibility of deceit in war
Chapter: It is disliked to wish to meet the enemy, and the command to be steadfast when meeting the enemy
Chapter: It is recommended to pray for victory when meeting the enemy
Chapter: War booty has been made permissible for this Ummah only
Chapter: The killer is entitled to the belongings of the one who is killed
Chapter: Additional rewards, and ransoming muslims in return for prisoners
Chapter: Ruling on Fai' (Booty acquired without fighting)
Chapter: The words of the Prophet (saws): "We (Prophets) have no heirs and whatever we leave behind is charity."
Chapter: The support of the angels during the Battle of Badr, and the permissibility of the spoils
Chapter: Expulsion of the Jews from the Hijaz
Chapter: Hastening to fight, and giving precedence to the more urgent of two tasks when a choice must be made
Chapter: The Battle of Hunain
Chapter: The Battle of At-Ta'if
Chapter: The Battle of Badr
Chapter: The truce of Al-Hudaybiyah
Chapter: Upholding Covenants
Chapter: The Battle of Al-Ahzab (The Confederates)
Chapter: The Battle of Uhud
Chapter: The intense wrath of Allah towards the one who was killed by the messenger of Allah (saws)
Chapter: The persecution suffered by the prophet (saws) at the hands of the idolaters and hypocrites
Chapter: The supplication of the Prophet (saws) and his steadfastness in the face of the hypocrites' persecution
Chapter: The slaying of Ka'b Bin Al-Ashraf, the Tagut of the Jews
Chapter: The Battle of Al-Ahzab (The Confederates), also known as Al-Khandaq (The Ditch)
Chapter: The Battle of Dhu Qarad and other battles
Chapter: The words of Allah, the Most High: "And He it is who has withheld their hands from you"
Chapter: Women participating in military expeditions with the men
Chapter: The number of campaigns of the Prophet (saws)
Chapter: The campaign of Dhat Ar-Riqa
Chapter: It is disliked to seek the help of a disbeliever in wars (except in cases of necessity, or if he thinks well of the Muslims)
Chapter: The people follow the Quraish and the Caliphate belongs to the Quraish
Chapter: It is disliked to be appointed to a position of authority unnecessarily
Chapter: The virtue of a just ruler and the punishment of a tyrant; Encouragement to treat those under one's authority with kindness and the prohibition against causing them hardship
Chapter: The obligation of obeying leaders in matters that do not involve sin, but it is forbidden to obey them in sinful matters
Chapter: The ruler is a shield from behind whom they fight and by whom they are protected
Chapter: The obligation of fulfilling oaths of allegiance is owed to the first of two Caliphs

Chapter: The obligation of staying with the Jama'ah (main body) of the muslims when Fitn (tribulations) appear, and in all circumstances. The prohibition of refusing to obey and on splitting away from the Jama'ah
Chapter: When allegiance has been sworn to two caliphs
Chapter: It is recommended for the army to swear allegiance to the ruler when intending to fight, and an account of Bay'at Ar-Ridwan beneath the tree
Chapter: The prohibition against a Muhajir returning to settle in his former homeland

Chapter: Swearing Allegiance and Pledging to adhere to Islam, to engage in Jihad and to do Good, after the conquest of Makkah, and the meaning of the phrase: "There is No Hijrah (migration) after the Conquest."
Chapter: Oath of allegiance pledging to hear and obey as much as possible
Chapter: The virtue of going out in the morning or the evening in the cause of Allah
Chapter: The High Positions that Allah has prepared for the Mujahid in Paradise
Chapter: The souls of the martyrs are in Paradise, and they are alive with their Lord and they have provision
Chapter: The virtue of helping the warrior who is fighting in the cause of Allah with mounts etc., and looking after his family in his absence
Chapter: Affirmation of Paradise for the Martyr
Chapter: It is recommended to seek Martyrdom in the Cause of Allah, Exalted is He.
Chapter: Criticism of one who dies without having fought (in Jihad) or having thought of fighting
Chapter: About the Martyrs
Chapter: The virtue of Shooting and Encouragement to learn it, and criticism of the one who learns it and then forgets it
Chapter: The words of the prophet saws: "A Group of my Ummah will continue to Prevail on the basis of the Truth, and They will not be Harmed by those who oppose them."
Chapter: Travel is a kind of torment, and it is recommended for the traveler to hasten back to his family after finishing his business
Chapter: The prohibition of eating the meat of domesticated donkeys
Chapter: The permissibility of eating the Dabb (mastigure)
Chapter: The prohibition of cornering animals in order to kill them (for sport)
Chapter: The age of sacrificial animals
Chapter: It is recommended to select a good animal for the sacrifice and to slaughter it oneself, not delegating it to anyone else, and to say the name of Allah, and to say the Takbir
Chapter: The prohibition of eating sacrificial meat for more than three days, which applied at the beginning of Islam but was then abrogated, and now it is permissible to eat it as long as one wants.
Chapter: Fara' and 'Atirah
Chapter: The prohibition of Khamr, which may be made from the juice of grapes, dried dates, unripe dates, raisins and other things that intoxicate
Chapter: The prohibition of making vinegar from wine
Chapter: The prohibition of using Khamr as a remedy; It is not a remedy
Chapter: The prohibition of making Nabidh in Al-Muzaffat, Ad-Dubba' (Gourds), Al-Hantam and An-Naqir; This has been abrogated and now it is permitted, so long as it does not become intoxicating
Chapter: Every intoxicant is Khamr and all Khamr is Haram
Chapter: The permissibility of Nabidh so long as it has not become strong and has not become intoxicating

Chapter: It is recommended to cover vessels, tie up waterskins, close doors and mention the name of Allah over them, extinguish lamps and fires when going to sleep, and keep children and animals in after maghrib
Chapter: The etiquette of eating and drinking, and rulings thereon
Chapter: Drinking while standing

Chapter: It is recommended to lick one's fingers and wipe the bowl, and to eat a piece of food that is dropped after removing any dirt on it. It is disliked to wipe one's hand before licking it, because of the possibility that the blessing of the food may be in that remaining part. The Sunnah is to eat with three fingers
Chapter: What the guest should do if he is accompanied by someone who was not invited by the host; it is recommended for the host to give permission to the one who has accompanied the guest
Chapter: It is permissible to take someone else to the house of one who you are certain will approve of that and will not mind. It is recommended to gather to eat
Chapter: Eating cucumbers with fresh dates
Chapter: The virtue of the dates of Al-Madinah
Chapter: The virtue of the black fruit from the Arak tree
Chapter: Honoring guests and the virtue of showing preference to one's guest
Chapter: The virtue of sharing a small amount of food, and the food of two is sufficient for three, and so on.
Chapter: The believer eats in one intestine and the disbeliever eats in seven intestines.

Chapter: The Prohibition Of Using Vessels Of Gold And Silver For Men And Women, And Gold Rings And Silk For Men, But They Are Permissible For Women. Permissibility Of Silken Borders On Garments For Men, But It Should Not Be More Than Four Fingers Wide
Chapter: Humility In Dress And Sticking To Coarse And Simple Clothes, Furnishings Etc., Permissibility Of Wearing Clothes Made From Camel Hair And Those On Which There Are Markings
Chapter: It Is Disliked To Have More Furniture And Bedding Than One Needs
Chapter: The Prohibition Of Letting One's Garment Drag Out Of Pride, And The Extent To Which It Is Permissible To Let It Hang Down And The Extent To Which It Is Recommended
